caption_text: Two scintillation detectors placed along the reactor and separated by a distance of 0.26 m are connected to an ORTEC amplification system linked to a multichan- nel analyzer supported by a 486 IBM compatible (see Fig. 1). They are shielded with thick lead bricks to minimize background radiation. They are not flushed with the bricks but 50 mm into the bricks in order to 713 CES 51/fi-D 714 M.
raw_window: Two scintillation detectors placed along the reactor and separated by a distance of 0.26 m are connected to an ORTEC amplification system linked to a multichan- nel analyzer supported by a 486 IBM compatible (see Fig. 1).
They are shielded with thick lead bricks to minimize background radiation.
They are not flushed with the bricks but 50 mm into the bricks in order to 713 CES 51/fi-D 714 M.

caption_text: Two typical distribution curves for sand particles are shown in Fig. 2 in the vigorously bubbling and the turbulent regimes. They show the existence of a large mean dispersion coeffic- ient and a large fluctuation in the bubbling regime as well as a small mean dispersion coefficient and less fluctuation in the turbulent regime. caption_text: (12) (X12 Agreement between the correlation and the data is shown in Fig. 6 and is quite satisfactory. The values of the mass transfer coefficient are of the same order of magnitude as the values reported by Werther (1980) and the correlation by van Swaij (1978) (Fig. 6) which predicts the height of a transfer unit. The parameter fl is almost constant at about 0.08 for sand particles and 0.11 for the FCC and the PC263 catalyst which is very low.
raw_window: (12) (X12 Agreement between the correlation and the data is shown in Fig. 6 and is quite satisfactory.

The values of the mass transfer coefficient are of the same order of magnitude as the values reported by Werther (1980) and the correlation by van Swaij (1978) (Fig. 6) which predicts the height of a transfer unit.
The parameter fl is almost constant at about 0.08 for sand particles and 0.11 for the FCC and the PC263 catalyst which is very low.

caption_text: The conversion data ob- tained in the turbulent regime ( Foka et al., 1994) with natural gas are presented in Fig. 7 along with the prediction of different models. The plug flow model obviously overpredicts the observed data. caption_text: (14) was used to model the reaction as shown in Fig. 7. It is clear from this figure that this model can also satisfactorily predict our data in a wide range of the number of reaction units. However, the complete catalytic combustion of natu- ral gas is a very simple reaction and a more complic- ated reaction is needed for model discrimination.

A limited number of experiments designed to 0.0o ~3 0 monitor simultaneously the bed porosity using 0.0 a capacitance probe and the mixing experiments are carried out in this reactor in the turbulent regime and the trend in the data compared quite well with the data of Li and Wu (1990) obtained for FCC particles in a 90 mm ID reactor i.e.
the dispersion coefficient decreases with porosity in the turbulent regime.
